key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse's trial for the shooting during a Wisconsin protest was delayed by 7 months.
The trial was rescheduled from March 29 to November 1, with a status hearing on May 17.
Rittenhouse faces multiple charges, including reckless homicide and being a minor in possession of a firearm.
The delay was requested by both prosecution and defense for more preparation time.
Rittenhouse, who was 17 at the time of the shooting, has argued he acted in self-defense.
The incident took place during protests that erupted after a white police officer shot Jacob Blake, leaving him paralyzed.
Rittenhouse is accused of killing two protesters and wounding a third with an AR-15-style rifle.
The case has become a focal point in debates over gun rights and racial injustice.
Rittenhouse has received support from conservatives, while others see him as a symbol of white supremacy.
The trial delay echoes broader legal reckonings with the Black Lives Matter movement and related incidents.
